SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name WILLIAM HODGSON.

Present Address BOX 478 KEIL ST. JEREMIAH MO. P.O. BRITISH COLUMBIA.

Pioneer Address MARSHALL, SASKATCHEWAN.

Year you came to Saskatchewan 1905.

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?
   About a dozen.
   How many of these were bachelor's homes? 8.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?
   Depended on the time of year. More often in winter.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday or other days?
   Always visited the married neighbors on Sundays, generally going up to Mrs. Smith's in town for dinner or staying until midnight.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?
   Invitations were necessary, as everyone was always pleased to see each other.
   What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?
   On Sundays, visiting the forenoon or afternoon.
   What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?
   You were always intended to stay meals.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly?
   (That is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)
   On a Sunday, the married ladies always had done quite a lot of cooking, so the ladies, as it was generally the day to go to church, got provisions, meat, &c.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?
   There was always the friendly cup of tea or home baked bread &c.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?
   The whole family would go when families visited, but would not stay as long as the bachelors as they had to get back to put the young ones to bed.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?
   Certainly, especially in case of sickness.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.
   The first was the building of Holy Trinity Church at Hartson during the winter of 1906-07. Around 1919, all the neighbors got busy, but in Mr. Sam Boyce's shop, as they were quarantined from the harvest-time around 1926, all helped to harvest Mr. Dynes' crop.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.
   Not many parties in the private homes, but during the winter we generally had a whist drive in the school, followed by a supper, then a dance once a month, sometimes these affairs would be continued until daylight, as it was not safe for anyone who had been out.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.
   No, I didn't think they grew as when the people began to move away, they were more for heading for the towns, etc.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?
   The first winter, a Mr. C. H. Watts & I used to go up to the Smiths' about three nights a week to play cards, so we were always up at Mrs. Ross Smith's for dinner & supper, etc., and they looked forward to us going, that if we missed they were worried that anything might have happened to us.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?
   About a dozen.
   How many of these were bachelor's homes? 8.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?
   Depending on the time of year. More often in winter.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?
   Always visited the married neighbors on Sundays, generally going up to the North in time for dinner, staying until bedtime.

4. Were you invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?
   No invitations were necessary as everyone was always pleased to see each other.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

On Sundays, during the forenoon or afternoon.

Did people ever invite you during a week for a meal, game of cards, etc.?

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

You were always intended to stay meals.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

On a Sunday, the married ladies always had done quite a lot of cooking on the 15th, so that was generally the day to go to church and get provisions, meat, etc.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

There was always the friendly cup of tea or home-baked bread and cake, which the bachelors went gladly to get.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

The whole family would go when families visited, but would not stay long as the bachelors as they had to get back to feed the young.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Certainly, especially in case of sickness.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

The first was the building of Holy Trinity Church at Hartown during the winter of 1906-07. Around 1919 all the neighbors got busy to put in Mr. Sam Ross's crop, as they were guaranteed 20% in the harvest-time around 1926 we all helped to harvest Mr. Dynan's crop.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Not many parties in the private homes, but during the winter we generally had a whist drive in the school, followed by a supper, then a dance once a month, sometimes three affairs would be continued until daylight, as it was not safe for anyone to be out.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates, come quite often.

No, I don't think they were, as when the people began getting cars they were more for heading off to town, etc.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once every a month, etc.?

The first winter, a Mr. C. Watts turned up to help the neighbors about three nights a week to play cards, etc., for fun. They always met at Mr. Ross' house for dinner and supper, etc., and they looked forward to his coming, that if he missed they were worried that something might have happened to him.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, pianos, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

We had our school drives, supper and dances as mentioned before, after the Christmas concert by the school pupils, followed by the lighting up of the Christmas tree, Santa arriving, distributing presents to all the children, also other private parties, then followed by supper and up with a dance. Before school started for the summer recess we had a big school dance, a candy rush for good boys in the afternoon, supper, then

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

In the early days most of the social life was really centered around the school, as everyone had jobs, late years when people got homes, one went further afield to the villages or hamlets, certainly when the cars made their appearance people went further away still.

9. What was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.? )

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

Certainly.

How were babies and small children provided for?

When the young ones were too tired to help anyone, they were laid down on the floor etc. in the corners, wrapped up with foot-cloths etc., until how were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? Time lost here.

As many horses were packed in the stable that could go, the remainder were tied to the side-alley fence, everyone bringing their own feed for horses.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

What was the most popular, but when first Bachelor got together they generally played Pulp, only two Crib, one of same old game.

Was there card playing for a prize?

At the Whist drives, always a Ladies' Crib, 1st, 2nd & 3rd prizes.

What dances were popular?

Waltz, Two Step, Round, Polka, Waltz, Military Two Step, Schottische, The Lancers, Square Dances etc.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

None whatever, everyone was there to meet each other & have a nice Social evening.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Some frowned upon either card playing or dancing.

18. Strongly opposed by others? Can't play yet.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.?

What are you trying to prove? Naturally, we always went visiting in respectable clothes, but me and "coats, etc.", you know, were on the side line of these, where the types were usually known as someone who was helping the origin train.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community?

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

The Harbours Grain Growers Association.

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Yes.

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Around 1908. Being a rural community all the farmers were anxious to learn what they could, so they belonged different associations.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it? All.

How many women belonged? None. How often did it meet? Every month.

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

Discussions on farming etc., the members would give a paper on a certain subject which would be discussed, we would try to have someone from the Experimental Farm give us a lecture.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? No.

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

What games did girls play in summer (-sliding down, play house, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
   Snowballing, sliding, tobogganing.

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?  
   Snap, dominoes, snakes & ladders etc.

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.  
   The whole family would join in for a time.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.  
   Generally we found time for games.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.  
   Building forts in winter or having a snowball battle.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.  
   March 1908.

26. Who organized it?  
   Strathmore Grain Growers Association.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
   Anybody who cared to come along.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? Yes.

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
   Tobogganing down the banks of the Battle River, and trying to skate on the Battle River with old country skates.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?  
   All eatables were provided by the Strathmore Grain Growers as far as I know. Tables were set up in a long prairie on the floor of Mr. Taylor's, with racks of grain around the walls to sit on.

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
   Sandwiches, salads, cakes or cookies to eat. Tea & Coffee to drink.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
   In the afternoon, started until day break next morning.

33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

Mr. Smith & Co. did not make very much progress about the Old Country "shades not being sharp enough for that hard uneven battle line," yes, but we had a good time. Worked up a good appetite, after supper the tables were cleared away to make room for dancing, consisting mainly of Scotch dances or square dances, to the music of violin or accordion.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnics, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

As soon as the cars became quite popular there was not the accessibility as in the early days.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

The only sports we held in the district in the early days were the Summer School Sports Day, which consisted of the children's races, the relay race, cricket game, football game.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

Association Football.

What year? 1913

How long did it continue? In 1914, The Hartown Hockey team won the Kyle Cup Trophy, placed down then during the First World War.

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

The Hartown Cricketers could generally manage to scrape up a team to play Marshall.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

The first sheet of ice was made outside in the fall of 1929, that was only used for skating on.

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

It has never been built yet to my knowledge. The nearest indoor rink being at Lloydminster.
